com.pb.sawdust.io

Class IterableFileReader.LineIterableReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.io.IterableFileReader.LineIterableReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IterableReader<java.lang.String>, RuntimeCloseable, java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.String>
    Enclosing class:
    IterableFileReader

    @ThreadSafe
public static class IterableFileReader.LineIterableReader
extends java.lang.Object
implements IterableReader<java.lang.String>
    The LineIterableReader is an iterable reader which is used to iterate over the lines in a file. It cannot be instantiated externally, but is made available through factory methods in the IterableFileReader class. It can only iterate through the file once, this is analogous to the fact that a buffered reader (whcih this class uses to read files) can effectively only read through a file once (the mark()...reset() paradigm only works within the length of the reader's buffer). Thus, any reference to it remaining after it has finished its iteration cycle should be set to null to allow it to be garbage collected. When the reader is finished iterating (i.e. when hasNext() == false), it will automatically be closed. This behavior can be changed by calling setCloseIterationAtEnd(boolean) appropriately. If the iterator is to be discarded before its iteration cycle has completed, then the close() method should be called explicitly.

    Though only one iterator may be created through this class, it is possible to access that iterator via multiple threads - this is safe as this class' iterator is thread-safe and guarded by this class' intrinsic object lock.

    • Method Detail

      • setCloseAtIterationEnd

        public void setCloseAtIterationEnd(boolean closeAtIterationEnd)
        Description copied from interface: IterableReader
        Set whether this reader's iterator should close the reader automatically at the end of the iteration cylce.
        Specified by:
        setCloseAtIterationEnd in interface IterableReader<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        closeAtIterationEnd - true if the reader should be closed at the end of the iteration, false if it is to be left open. If false, then close() generally should be called explicitly when iteration is finshed.

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.String> iterator()
        Get an iterator which will iterate over the lines in the file associated with this reader. If an io exception occurs during this iterators operation, then an RuntimeIOException will be thrown.
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.String>
        Returns:
        a line iterator.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the iterator for this instance has already been accessed through this method, or if the iterator is used after this reader is closed..

      • close

        public void close()
        Description copied from interface: RuntimeCloseable
        Closes this stream and releases any system resources associated with it. If the stream is already closed then invoking this method has no effect. This is identical to the method prescribed in java.io.Closeable, except it has no checked exception.
        Specified by:
        close in interface RuntimeCloseable
        Specified by:

        Specified by:

      • finalize

        public void finalize()
              throws java.lang.Throwable
        This method is overridden in this class to ensure that the file has been closed when this object is garbage collected. This should not be used as a replacement for calling close() explicitly in code, just to ensure that the resources are properly freed up in unexpected or exceptional situations.
        Overrides:
        finalize in class java.lang.Object
        Throws:
        java.lang.Throwable
